title: Predictive vs Adaptive
description: Select the appropriate development approach (predictive, adaptive, hybrid) based on project characteristics—requirements stability, uncertainty, compliance, and culture.
objectives: Select the appropriate development approach (predictive, adaptive, hybrid) based on project characteristics
Distinguish between change control in predictive vs change embrace in adaptive approaches
Apply hybrid strategies for organizational transitions from predictive to adaptive
Recognize when continuous planning and tailoring are appropriate

screens.headline: Three projects, three different contexts. Ava wants all three using Agile: 'I heard it's faster and more customer-focused.' But is one approach right for all?

items.label: Menu Innovation
items.detail: Sticky notes flying, creative exploration, high uncertainty

items.label: Kitchen Renovation
items.detail: Gantt chart, compliance documents, fixed requirements

dialogue.text: Not all projects need the same approach. Match each project to the right method—predictive, adaptive, or hybrid—based on requirements stability, uncertainty, and compliance constraints.

screens.learningHook: Learn to match approach to context. Agile embraces change (no CCB). Predictive controls change (with CCB). Hybrid combines both strategically.

screens.title: Approach Selection
screens.instructions: Match each project to the right development approach based on its characteristics. Justify your choice.

scenarios.title: Menu Innovation Sprint
description: Requirements: LOW stability—creative fusion cuisine, customer preferences unknown.
Uncertainty: HIGH—experimental dishes, need frequent feedback.
Stakeholders: Highly involved, want weekly tastings.

questions.question: Which approach is best for Menu Innovation?

options.text: Predictive—Detailed upfront planning, Change Control Board
Adaptive—Progressive elaboration, no CCB, iterative cycles

feedback.correct: Adaptive is ideal: HIGH uncertainty, LOW compliance, frequent feedback needed. Weekly tastings, rapid iteration, creative exploration. No CCB—customer feedback drives backlog directly.
feedback.incorrect: High uncertainty + low compliance + need for feedback = Adaptive. Predictive would lock you into dishes before knowing customer preferences.

scenarios.title: Kitchen Renovation
description: Requirements: HIGH stability—building codes, equipment specs, health regulations.
Compliance: HIGH—health inspector, building permits required.
Deliverable: Sequential phases—design, permits, construction, inspection.

questions.question: Which approach is best for Kitchen Renovation?

options.text: Predictive—Detailed upfront planning, Change Control Board
Adaptive—Progressive elaboration, no CCB, iterative cycles

feedback.correct: Predictive is required: HIGH compliance (health codes, permits), LOW uncertainty (known process), fixed requirements. You cannot 'iterate' with a health inspector—plans must be approved upfront.
feedback.incorrect: Regulatory requirements are non-negotiable. Installing equipment without permits violates codes. Predictive with Change Control Board is mandatory for compliance.

scenarios.title: Catering Service Launch
description: Requirements: MIXED—core menu (fixed for health permits) + service model (evolving based on corporate client feedback).
Compliance: PARTIAL—menu needs health approval, service model doesn't.

questions.question: Which approach is best for Catering Launch?

options.text: Predictive—Detailed upfront planning, Change Control Board
Adaptive—Progressive elaboration, no CCB, iterative cycles
Hybrid—Predictive for core menu (compliance), Adaptive for service model (evolving)

feedback.correct: Hybrid is strategic: Core menu needs predictive (health permits, compliance). Service model needs adaptive (evolving based on client feedback). De-risk the core while staying flexible on features.
feedback.incorrect: Mixed requirements = Hybrid approach. Some elements benefit from predictive (compliance), others need adaptive (user experience).

content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 7th Ed pages 177-179; Agile Practice Guide pages 9-12

comparison.hybrid: CCB for core, agile for features

insights.insight: Agile embraces change; Predictive controls change
insights.detail: No CCB in adaptive approaches. Customer feedback drives backlog directly.
Used when some elements benefit from predictive (compliance), others need adaptive (user experience).
Risk-averse culture may need hybrid transition. Can't force agile into hierarchical orgs overnight.

insights.insight: Lean principles: Decide late + Deliver fast
insights.detail: Keep options open as long as possible. Maximize flow and speed of delivery.

misconceptions.correct: Context matters—match approach to project characteristics
Hybrid is strategic for mixed requirements or transitions
Regulations are non-negotiable—use predictive for compliance
No CCB in pure adaptive approaches—customer feedback drives backlog

correct.text: Adaptive is perfect for Menu Innovation. Weekly tastings, rapid iteration, creative exploration. Customer feedback drives what dishes we develop—no upfront lock-in.
You cannot 'iterate' with a health inspector. Kitchen Renovation needs predictive: approved plans, permits, sequential phases. Compliance isn't optional.

screens.title: Convince Carlos on Hybrid
screens.context: Carlos pushes back: 'Hybrid sounds complicated. Just pick one—predictive or agile. We don't have time for both.'

questions.question: For Catering Launch, why plan menu and permits PREDICTIVELY?

options.text: To avoid compliance issues—inspectors require approved plans
Service needs to evolve based on corporate client feedback we can't predict

questions.question: How should you address Carlos's 'complexity' concern?

options.text: 'You're right, let's just use predictive for everything.'
'Hybrid isn't more complex—it's TAILORED. We de-risk the core (predictive) while staying flexible on features (adaptive).'

screens.title: Approach Selection Mastery
screens.summary: You've learned to select the right development approach based on requirements stability, uncertainty, compliance, and organizational context. Match approach to project—don't force agile everywhere.
takeaways: Agile embraces change (no CCB); Predictive controls change (with CCB)
Match approach to project context—requirements stability, uncertainty, compliance
Hybrid is strategic for mixed requirements or organizational transitions
Culture influences approach success—can't force agile into hierarchical orgs overnight
Lean principles: Decide as late as possible, deliver as fast as possible

artifacts.title: Approach Selection Reference
artifacts.description: Decision tree, Predictive vs Adaptive comparison table, Hybrid use cases

characterClosing.text: I thought agile was always better. Alex showed me: Match approach to context. Menu Innovation needs adaptive (uncertainty). Kitchen Renovation needs predictive (compliance). Catering Launch needs hybrid (mixed). One size doesn't fit all.
